That the committee approves the statement on the Issues from the Advance to the Minister for Finance as a final charge for the year ended 30 June 1998.

talk.start.para: âOf course, we have just had the spectacle in relation to the appropriation bills of the government accepting their guilt on the issue of the unconscionable $20 million advertising campaign that was conducted in the lead-up to the last election. This expenditure is totally unprecedented in the history of Australian politics. I think it is quite extraordinary that not only did such a second reading amendment find favour in the Senateâmany would expect that that might be the case, given that the government does not in its own right hold a majority hereâbut the government, so ashamed of its own behaviour, did not even see fit to divide on this issue.

speech.para: The opposition has, for many months, drawn attention to what we consider to be an absolutely flagrant abuse of taxpayers' moneyâan abuse of power on the part of this government in terms of this totally improper and unprecedented use of taxpayers' money. We have never seen, in the history of Australian politics, a government spend so much money in the lead-up to an election campaign. We have never seen a situation where those moneys were spent not on advertising and promoting a government program but on promoting a policy that the government intended to take to the election itself.
Progress reported.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI inform the Senate that Senator Robert Hill, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage and Minister representing the Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and the Minister for Forestry and Conservation will be absent from the Senate for question time this week. Senator Hill is attending the seventh session of the Commission on Sustainable Development in New York. During Senator Hill's absence, I shall take questions relating to the Prime Minister's portfolio, the Trade portfolio and the Foreign Affairs portfolio. Senator Minchin will take questions relating to the Environment and Heritage portfolio, and the Forestry and Conservation portfolio.

âby leaveâAs you, Madam President, would be aware, it is not normally the case that the opposition comments when the Leader or Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate makes a statement about ministerial arrangements. I wanted to point out on this occasion the absolute hypocrisy of the government in relation to this issue. Time and again, when the Labor Party was itself in government and found that a minister was required to be absent, whether overseas on ministerial business or caught up in a ministerial council or some unavoidable appointment in Australia, we had Senator Hill claiming on behalf of the then opposition that those ministers should be present in the chamber.

speech.para: I point out the cant and hypocrisy in the statements that Senator Hill made at that time. The record stands for itself. I commend the Hansard record of 16 November 1993, 6 December 1993, 22 March 1994, 11 May 1994, 19 September 1994, 23 March 1995, 25 September 1995 and 14 November 1995, when Senator Hill, on behalf of the then opposition, strenuously objected when Senator Gareth Evansâthe then Leader of the Government in the Senateâor another minister was absent from the chamber during question time. In fact, I will quote Senator Hill from 16 October 1995, when Senator Evansâwho was then not the Minister for the Environment but the Minister for Foreign Affairsâannounced that he would be absent, and then was absent, from the chamber. What did Senator Hill say? Let me quote him:
. . . forget the responsibilities of the government and ministers to this parliament because he has better things to do.
He said of Senator Evans that he ought to recognise his responsibility to the Australian parliament. I quote him again:
This minister puts his other activities ahead of that responsibility and for that I think he should be condemned.
He went on in that same statement at great length to say:
In the view of the coalition this is unsatisfactory and he should meet his first responsibility and that is his responsibility to the Australian parliament.

We do not engage here in an exercise of hypocrisy. We do acceptâunlike the coalitionâthat ministers of the Crown have responsibilities that might take them away from this parliament and from a sitting of the Senate on certain occasions. We are not critical of that, but we are critical of the consistent hypocrisy that Senator Hill showed during his period as opposition leader.

There is no way in the world that the coalition, when in opposition, would have accepted the situation where Senator Hill did not himself deliver, but had a member of his staff deliver, a letter to my office late on Friday, 16 April last week, saying that Senator Hill would be absent from the chamber today and for the remainder of the week. If that situation had been repeated when Labor was in government, we would have had this chamber up-ended for at least half an hour before question time commenced. There is a serious issue here of consistency, and the Liberal Party in coalition government stands condemned for the most hypocritical approach imaginable to this issue.

We do accept that Senator Hill has business overseas. We are unhappy that the Prime Minister has seen fit to have his doormat represent him here in the Senate chamber this week. But we will not be engaging in the same sort of whingeing hypocrisy that we saw from Senator Hill and the Liberals throughout the life of the last Labor government, when consistently the then opposition drew attention to such absences from the chamber. However, we do ask that Senator Hill and the government show a little more courtesy than they showed on this occasion. Obviously, the dates for the Commission on Sustainable Development were well knownâprobably when the Senate determined to sit in this weekâand it is unsatisfactory for the parliament to be informed just a couple of days prior to Senator Hill's absence that he would be overseas. That is a substantive point, and we would ask that the government lift its game.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Alston. Is the minister aware of comments by Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, to the effect that Victoria `may as well not have' federal ministers from that state, including the minister himself and the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, because `they're not advocates for Victoria, they don't go into bat for us on anything'? What action has the Prime Minister taken to improve the poor relationship between Victorian ministers and the state Premier, and what action has the minister or any of his colleagues taken to reassure Mr Kennett that they are actually trying to do their best?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âIf you put the organ grinder and the monkey together, what you get is really a complaint that Senator Hill was not here to hear the first bit of entertainment. It is a reasonable proposition but it is not a serious question in the context of national politics, because there is clearly a whole raft of other issues. Having said that, let me say that there is a good working relationship with the Victorian Premier and with several other premiers, including Premier Beattie and Premier Carr. I am sure you are aware of their very supportive remarks of the federal government at the last Premiers Conference when Premier Beattie actually said that the government has a mandate to get its tax package through the Senate. Mr Carr, straight after the last election, made similar commentsâthat governments with a majority in the lower house should not be held hostage to fortune by minorities in the upper house.

answer.para: We take the view that it is important to get on with all premiers and we are delighted that Premiers Beattie and Carr are so supportive of us that they are prepared to walk away from you lot. Do you know why? They know the big lesson from last time around. They know that in opposition you are entitled to oppose but that what the Australian public will not abide is unprincipled opposition. In other words, if they think you have a genuine philosophical point of difference, then they can accept that and maybe even respect itâbut not when you have opportunistic opposition where you support one thing in government and another in opposition. Remember what Mrs Kernot had to say? I do not know whether she has ever recanted, but what she effectively said was, `I am not so worried about Labor in opposition on Telstra; what worries me is what they would do in government.' That is the problem. As far as Mr Kennett is concerned, what the Prime Minister did to ensure that relationships were very harmonious was to come out and make some complimentary remarks about the calibre of those in the cabinet from Victoria.

But the essential point of difference is this. At the end of the day, they are not just there to represent Victorian interests. I know you blokes cannot understand this. If you are here, there is only one reason why: because the union said you could have a run on the ball or because some sort of factional deal was done that put you in, irrespective of merit. Look at Senator Carr. Can anyone suggest for a moment that he is here on merit? Of course not. These blokes are here because deals were done that put them here. You are not here simply to represent your state. Cast your mind back to Edmund Burke. You have probably never heard of Edmund Burke; you are probably lost with Burke and Wills. Edmund Burke actually made a very important distinction about why you are elected to parliament. You are there not beholden to the interests that put you there; you are there to represent the interests of the community at large. That is what you have to understand. I am sure Senator Ray in his heart of hearts knows all this. I am delighted that Days of our Lives is obviously not on today and he has managed to get into question time at the very beginning of the session, and that is highly commendable, but I think he understands that at the end of the day Victoria will not be neglected by this federal government. What I suggest you do, if you are really worried about Victoria's interests, is get yourself a decent leader down there and get a decent team together, but I am afraid it is too late.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, on the assumption Sesame Street has not started early, I ask a supplementary question. When the minister refers to people being in this chamber on their merit and not as a result of factional deals, is he asserting that Senator Synon was demoted down the ticket in Victoria on the basis of ability or that it was a factional deal? Coming back to Mr Kennett's comments, is the minister saying that Mr Kennett has retracted his remarks about Victorian ministers, that he has retracted his remarks about Victoria being dudded at the Grants Commission, and that he has retracted his remarks that he believes that parliament might as well move to Sydney because you and your colleagues are basically useless?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThat is a very liberal paraphrase of what I understood Mr Kennett to be saying. The fact is that he did feel the need to get something off his chest in the lead-up to the Premiers Conference. You understand that as well as we do. If Senator Ray is something other than the absentee member for Victoria Parkâin other words, if he is really here and concerned about Victoria's interestsâthen start standing up for them and tell us where Victoria is being neglected.
âWe are not in cabinet.

âBut I am always sufficiently open-minded to take account of quality advice. So if you have something to say on the subject, by all means say it, but I have not heard a word from you. There are a lot of issues like the one about Sydney-centric government and Victoria being left behind, but I have never heard a word out of you. I suppose you are too busy on the phone giving Senator Conroy his instructions, but just go back to looking at Victoria's issues and you will have a lot to say. (Time expired)
âMadam President, my questionâ
âOnly 73 days to go.

âI raise a point of order, Madam President. One can understand Senator Faulkner's acute level of frustration, but is it appropriate for him, effectively having wasted the first 10 minutes, to now ensure that Senator Synon has the utmost difficulty in asking a question? I ask you, when he does it repeatedly, to bring him to order.
âIt is disorderly to keep interjecting.

âMadam President, on that point of order, I do hope that if Senator Alston continues his habit of taking spurious points of order you will pull him up, sit him down and apply the standing orders of the Senate fairly in relation to interjections.

âMy question of a substantive policy nature and not of personalities is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Alston. Under the dynamic economic management of the Howard government, the Australian economy stands as a powerhouse of the region and the fastest growing economy in the OECD. Minister, what measures has the Howard government taken to achieve this strong economic growth? Further, will the minister inform the Senate of the latest labour force figuresâwhich the opposition certainly will not want to hearâand outline how the government will continue to encourage this strong and sustained job growth?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI certainly acknowledge Senator Synon's very keen and ongoing interest in substantive policy issues. That is really what it ought to be all about, but once again there only seems to be one side interested in policy. Senator Synon quite rightly draws attention to what others have described as the `miracle economy'. Paul Krugman might be somewhat controversial, but I have not read too many people quarrelling with his assessment, because it all stacks up when you look at these numbers. Look at the real numbers. The real numbers are not those that get you onto the drip for life and keep you in here irrespective; the real numbers are what drive the economy. That is where the funds come from to pay for all the burdens that you impose on the taxpayer.

answer.para: GDP grew by 1.1 per cent in the last quarter, annualised at 4.7 per cent. All the forecasts suggest continuing robust economic growth. Inflation on a headline basis was 1.6 per cent through the year to the December quarter. It has been under two per cent for the last two yearsâthe best sustained inflation outcome in over 30 years. What was the average under Labor? Over five per cent. Unemployment is 7.4 per cent. Where did it get to in the 13 years under Labor? It managed to get up to 11.2 per centâabout a 50 per cent higher figure than we have achieved in the last three years. Unemployment is now down to its lowest level since 1990.

The absolutely fundamental outcomes of the responsible economic management that has been put in place by the government are reflected in the home loan interest rates, which are now around 6.5 per cent. How high did they get under Labor? They were 17 per cent. These are horrific numbers. When you draw that comparison, you can understand why they ran a mile and why they do not want to go back to you under any circumstances. What that translates to is an interest saving of over $330 a month on a $100,000 home loan.

Job Network is finding more jobs and attracting more vacancies than the old CES. Private health insurance rebates and increased funds for health have been made available, as well as increased funds for education. There are an additional 71,000 child-care places. We do not pretend for a moment that the game is over and that we do not need to do any more. It is a never ending challenge, but I think everyone who looks at the figures would have to say that we are well on track. In terms of the labour force, the figures that came out only a few days ago showed that youth unemployment continued its fall in trend terms to reach 23.4 per centâthe lowest level since January 1991. Male employment grew by 18,100, largely as a result of an increase in male full-time jobs. You say that is what it is all about; that is what is being delivered.

The premiers understand that, if you are to fix up the tax system, you need to secure the revenue base. You need to add to those numbers by having a comprehensive overhaul of the taxation system. If we do not do that, the premiers understand as well as we doâand of course you do in your heart of heartsâthat you will not be able to have increased spending on hospitals, roads, schools, bridges and the like. Therefore, it is critically important to acknowledge what it is that has taken the Australian economy to where it is. It is not just good luck or happenstanceâit is good economic management. It is in the teeth of criticism from the other side of politics, who have never espoused the sensible policy decisions but who have been utterly opportunistic. We will not be distracted. We will continue to address the issues.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, my question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Alston. Was the Prime Minister's mistaken claim on regional television that Australian workers pay more income tax than any country in the OECD except Denmark a deliberate attempt to mislead Australians, or was it the result of poor staff work? Will the Prime Minister correct the record in the parliament now? Will he apologise to Channel 7 for using their airwaves to spread misinformation? Can the minister also confirm that the Prime Minister, in his fireside chat to regional Australia, claimed that Australian workers paid 23 per cent of their wages in tax compared to 18 per cent in America, 17 per cent in Britain and 10 per cent in France? Can the minister confirm that these figures come directly from table 1 of the OECD report and that that report lists Australia after Belgium, Finland and Sweden, as well as Denmark?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThis is a classic case study for all those who are wanting to do PhDs on how some people succeed in politics and others do not. All they have to do is look at the way Senator Cook reacted to a snide and dishonest little exercise on the part of Mr Crean. If you just took Mr Crean's proposition at face value and you saw how it was retold in the media, there might be a basis for a question. I am not saying in any shape or form that it could be substantiated or justified, but if you believed Mr Crean for a momentâwhich we do notâthen you might have some basis for asking a question. But when you read the press release put out by the Prime Minister following that program, you would at the very least have had the intellectual challenge of having to distinguish your position from that of the Prime Minister. So what do you do? You take the easy way outâyou do not address the rebuttal. In other words, you just take what Mr Crean says as fact and you think that by recycling and peddling that you can make some progress.

answer.para: Let me tell you this. In his prime address, the Prime Minister said:
According to a recent study by the OECD, Australian workers on average wages pay more in income tax than workers in any other industrialised country in the world except Denmark.

Those words were based on the statement contained in table 2. The OECD report also contained table 1. There is no law that says if you quote table 2 you cannot quote from table 1 at the same time, is there? I do not think there is. But what you want to pretend is that because he used some table 2 figures, then everything else he said must have derived from table 2 as well. That is simply not the case. In giving those statistics, he quoted from table 1âabout 23 per cent of average Australian workers' wages is consumed by income tax compared with 18 per cent in America, et cetera. In other words, he quoted from both table 1 and table 2. If you are too lazy to go back and look at all the facts and to understand what the Prime Minister's response has been, then naturally enough you will get it fundamentally wrong. At the end of the day I suppose that is where you want to be. You want to try and muddy the waters. You want to try and pretend that something was said that was not said. You have failed absolutely abysmally. You have not even attempted to refute the Prime Minister's statement. Therefore there is nothing to apologise for, nothing that was got wrong. The only thing that was got wrong was got wrong by you, in misunderstanding the difference between table 1 and table 2.

talk.start.para: âThat is the slipperiest answer I have ever heard in politics. Minister, can you then explain why the Prime Minister yesterday issued a press release, as you have said, claiming he was quoting from table 2 of the report, when that table relates to an entirely different matter and contains totally different figures to those quoted by the Prime Minister?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âOnce again, let us be clear. Table 1 refers to the percentage of gross wage earnings paid in income tax and employees' social security contributions. Table 2 refers to income tax plus employees' and employers' social security contributions as a percentage of labour costs. There is absolutely nothing to say that you cannot quote from either one or the other or both, and that is exactly what the Prime Minister did. I am sorry that you cannot walk and chew gum at the same time, but he can and he did very successfully. The editorial from the Australian newspaper on 6 April made that overall point: that only Denmark ranks higher in a survey of the level of income tax paid on an average wage as a proportion of gross wages in the 28 nations making up the OECD.

answer.para: Senator Cook interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âDo you say that somehow you should not quote from table 1? Do you say, `Once you have quoted from table 2 you are stuck with it,' or vice versa?
âSenator Alston, your remarks should be directed to the Chair.
âWell, of course, Madam President, that is a nonsense proposition. (Time expired)

âMy question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. The recent Premiers Conference was unprecedented, at least in recent Australian political history, as all state and territory leaders left Canberra satisfied that the conference had achieved a positive resolution that would see them emerge better off. Will the Assistant Treasurer inform the Senate how the Australian states and territories will be better off as a result of the Premiers Conference?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Coonan for that very important question. It is true that after the last Premiers Conference quite a number of very happy chappies left Canberra, it has to be said, as a result of the agreement that was reached. Senator Coonan is a senator from Australia's most populous state and like us all has a great interest in the result of the Premiers Conference. The extraordinarily successful Premiers Conference represents a landmark agreement that will transform Commonwealth-state financial relations in this country. The Commonwealth government has agreed to provide the states and territories with a guaranteed, stable source of revenue to fund important community services. They in turn will abolish nine inefficient state taxes, which will remove their reliance on these growth reducing taxes and charges. Importantly, the agreement will end the states' and territories' reliance on current financial assistance grantsâthe so-called FAGs.

answer.para: In each transitional year of the implementation of the GST the Commonwealth will compensate any state whose budgetary position is temporarily worse off, and as the GST revenue increases each state will receive a larger financial gain. The new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement has also been established to provide funding to meet increased public housing costs. Senator Coonan, your Premier was unambiguous about his views on the government's right to implement a legislative program. If I can quote Senator Carrâand this is what Senator Carr, the ALP Premierâ

talk.start.para: âMr Carr.
âMr Carr. I never quote Senator Kim Carr. This is what Premier Carr said:

answer.para: My view is that a government with a majority in any lower house ought to be able to implement its program, not subject to frustration by upper house, state or federal, and be judged by the people three or four years down the track.
Let me stress that this is a comment from a recently elected Labor Premier, and I think that sends a very clear message. Premier Carr commented after the Premiers Conference:

I would put it this way. I have long been a child of the Whitlam era, of the view that when governments win elections they do have mandates. As someone who subscribes to an old-fashioned reformist belief that lower house majorities ought to prevail, I am very uncomfortable with upper houses blocking the will of the government of the day.
That is the view of Premier Carr. The New South Wales Treasurer, Mr Michael Egan, agrees with his Premier. This is what the Labor Treasurer of New South Wales said:
The real purpose of an election is to determine the will of the people and to appoint a government with a mandate to govern.

Premier Peter Beattie, the Labor Premier of the third-largest state, Queensland, said that the Howard government had got a mandate for the GST at the last election, and that of course he would not be obstructionist. Significantly, there were very supportive comments from Premier Jim Bacon of Tasmania, a Labor Premier. He said:
I am the first Tasmanian leader to go to Canberra and come away not worse off.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Alston representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister confirm the foreign minister's assessment that the Indonesian government in Jakarta is not `in favour of the sorts of activities that have been taking place' in East Timor? Can the minister advise whether this assessment encompasses the leadership of ABRI and in particular Defence Minister Wiranto? Can the minister also inform the Senate, in light of Mr Downer's view that rogue elements within the Indonesian army are culpable for the unfolding tragedy in East Timor, what representations the Australian government has made to the civilian leadership in Jakarta beyond the making of, in Mr Downer's words, `the right noises'?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI think it is fair to say that the government is very concerned about the situation in East Timor, particularly the response of the Indonesian government. What Mr Downer was pointing to was that the Indonesian government is not monolithic and, in particular, the relationship between the civilian government and the military is probably a lot more complex than it is in this country where there is a clear policy superiority in the Australian context vested in the hands of the civilian minister. As far as ABRI is concerned, I think what Mr Downer was pointing to was that there would appear to be some elements of the old guard who prefer the old regime to the quite substantial changes that have been implemented and the further changes foreshadowed by the Prime Minister. Certainly, President Habibie has indicated that he does wish the situation in East Timor to be resolved in terms of not only the escalating violence but also the killings that have been given wide publicity in recent times.

answer.para: It is the view of the Australian government that from the President down there is a commitment to try to ensure that the government and the armed forces act as decisively as possible to stop the violence. We do not underestimate the difficulties that are faced by the Indonesian government in ensuring that, throughout the armed forces, that approach is implemented. It is therefore imperative in the Australian government's view that the armed forces disarm the militias and that those responsible for the violence be brought to account. We have made our views known on a number of occasions, certainly through our ambassador to Jakarta in discussions with Foreign Minister Alitas and presidential adviser Dewi Fortuna Anwar as recently as 17 April.

The Prime Minister has indicated that he will contact President Habibie further. We certainly support an impartial investigation of the most recent deplorable incidents resulting in loss of life. We are trying to address these matters at different levels. We understand the difficulties faced by the Indonesian government, but we do think that they have a very important leadership role in terms of the actions of ABRI. We very much hope that the government's view will prevail.

talk.start.para: âMy question is also to Senator Alston on the same subject. My question refers to the report compiled for the Minister for Foreign Affairs by two Australian diplomats in East Timor following the massacre in Liquica last week. According to the Australian investigation, how many deaths occurred in Liquica as a result of the militia attacks on 6 April? Did the investigation establish any involvement by ABRI in the massacre either directly or through lack of intervention? If the Australian government does not believe that General Wiranto is involved in the violence in East Timor, will the government be making representations to President Habibie to request that he place generals in East Timor who will follow his orders for the maintenance of peace and order in that territory? If the violence leads to Jakarta abandoning the autonomy vote which is scheduled for July or August, what does the Australian government plan to do?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI think it is not helpful and perhaps not even sensible to look well down the track in terms of the responses which might be unfolding. In terms of the recent events about which we are very concerned and any report by the embassy in relation to the events at Liquica, which has been visited by embassy officers, it is not a matter that the government would be in the habit of releasing a report on, certainly at this stage. The visit was conducted to obtain a more accurate picture of what occurred in order to decide the appropriate Australian response. The release of the report, which contains the names of those who provided information, might well compromise the safety of contacts who spoke to our embassy.

answer.para: It is also correct to say that it is always very difficult to obtain an accurate picture of what occurred because you will get conflicting estimates of both the extent of the fatalities and the nature of the violence. Certainly, the extent of ABRI's involvement is a matter of particular concern. ABRI's estimate is one that has been provided to the government. But, again, I do not think that we would necessarily want to take any estimate of the nature and extent of the violence or the killings as being the final word on the subject.

The government does not see that it would serve any useful purpose to release that report, but it will certainly hopefully help to inform any decisions that the Australian government might take and certainly help to make us more aware of whatever contribution we might be able to make down the track. We do, I might say, welcome the Indonesian government's stated support for the National Commission for Human Rights fact finding mission currently in East Timor and for access to Liquica by the ICRC. The government also welcomes President Habibie's support for the establishment of a peace commission on East Timor under the auspices of Komnas Ham.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister. I am aware of the circumstances he is working under; he is not even the minister representing in general. I am not asking for the release of any names of any informants or anything like that, but what I would like to know is how many deaths were estimated to have occurred in Liquica as a result of the militia attacks on 6 April. I am sure there is a figure in that report which would not harm anybody if it became public. Will the government make representations to the President of Indonesia that he put people in charge in ABRI in Indonesia who will do what he has asked and what he has commanded them to do, which is to restore law and order, because it looks from the outside as if that is not happening?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe government has no reason to believe that President Habibie does not have a commitment to ensuring that those who are based in East Timor, either the representatives of the government directly or representatives of the armed forces, have that commitment. That is certainly a matter that I am sure will be further explored by the Prime Minister in any further discussions with President Habibie about the matter.

answer.para: I do not think anyone can contest that there have been killings both in Liquica on 5 and 6 April and in Dili over the weekend of 17 and 18 April. Once again, to simply publicise a number, which may or may not be an accurate one at this stage, we do not believe would contribute to any sensible resolution of the problem. I think the more important matter of principle is to try and ensure that the Indonesian government is very much aware of Australia's concerns and those of the international community and that whatever can be done from the highest levels is done. As I say, we have no reason to believe that President Habibie does not have that commitment, but that matter will nonetheless be reinforced by the Prime Minister. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Alston, representing the Prime Minister. Can the minister confirm that on the Sunday program yesterday the Prime Minister said, `it could be possible that the arrangement whereby pensions are always 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings, that the amount of that could over time be higher than the CPI, plus 1Â½ per cent', that Laurie Oakes prompted, `Could swallow up the 1Â½ per cent?' and that Mr Howard responded, `Yeah. Well, that has always been the case'? Hasn't the Prime Minister now finally confirmed what everybody knowsâthat the government's compensation package for pensioners will be eroded to zero, while the GST is forever?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI did see a newspaper report of remarks to that effect, I think in the Canberra Times . I am not in a position to make any comment on it, but the last thing I would do is take Senator Faulkner's assessment of it at face value. Going to the thrust of his question, the fact is that everything he needs to know and more is contained in an article that appears in the Financial Review today over the name of the Treasurer. What Mr Costello spells out there, chapter and verse, is that what Professor Warren noted in his study was that, on average, there appear to be no groups who are losers from the new tax system. He pointed out:

answer.para: The Government will be increasing pensions and other social security payments by 4 per cent from the day the GST commences. Pensioners will not have to wait for indexation adjustments to follow pricesâfor the first time, they will get increases before any price rise.

After that, pension and other social security indexation will be paid so that benefits will be 1.5 per cent higher than the full Consumer Price Index, with no discounting for tobacco or anything else.
He went on to talk about Professor Warren and the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling having missed the point with much of their study. He stated:
They seem to have thought the Government's policy is to provide a fixed pension increase of 3.4 per cent . . . regardless of prices . . .

This is not so. It is at least 4 per cent and no discounting. If the CPI goes higher indexation increases to be always 1.5 per cent above it. The 1.5 per cent "buffer" . . . ensures that even if . . . some people have above-average cost of living effects, they will still be covered. And it means those with lower than average costs will do even better.
And on he went. He then said:
. . . pensions will increase by an up-front 4 per cent and be maintained at 1.5 per cent more than prices. If, in the future, 25 per cent of MTAWEâ
that is, male total average weekly earningsâ
is higher, then pensions will rise again, rising further in front of prices. In this scenario pensioners get higher real increases.

Once again, what you have is an up-front commitment to ensuring that those on low incomes are fully protected. How does that stand in marked contrast to what Labor didâand you have never resiled from this, have you?âwith its l-a-w law? It is bad enough to fundamentally welsh on the most solemn of commitments, but what you did in the 1993-94 budget, without a cent of compensation for low income earners, was increase wholesale sales taxes by two per cent; put petrol up by 7c and 5c; increase excise on tobacco by 15 per cent; tighten the safety net for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme; restrict access to Medicare benefits; for optometry services reduce the growth; and push the pension age for women up to 65. Then in 1995-96âyou were repeat offendersâyou increased the Medicare levy by 0.1 per cent; increased tobacco tax by 10 per cent; and tried to impose a tax on the family home through the builders hardware tax.

When we are talking about compensation for tax increases, we have put it on the table. We have a very fair and equitable proposal that I think has been spelt out chapter and verse by the Treasurer. It stands in absolutely stark contrast to your total failure to provide even one cent of compensationâsomething which you have not only not apologised for but which, presumably, you would do again if ever you got the chance.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for drawing my attention to today's Financial Review article. I notice that the minister did not quote that Mr Costello said in today's Financial Review :

question.para: that is, the CPI plus 1.5 per cent and the 25 per cent of MTAWE benchmarkâ

Can the minister explain Mr Costello's statement in the light of Mr Howard's acceptance that the existing MTAWE benchmark will in fact swallow up the CPI plus 1.5 per cent? Who's lying hereâMr Howard or Mr Costello?

talk.start.para: âSenator, I do not think that is the appropriate way to phrase your question.
âI will rephrase it, Madam President. Who's telling the truthâMr Howard or Mr Costello?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI can simply assure the Senate that in relation to these matters, as in all others, both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have told the absolute truth. They have been quite transparent in their approach. They have had a deep commitment to ensuring that those on low incomes will be fully compensated. If Senator Faulkner is grateful to me for drawing his attention to the article, can I suggest he goes that one step further and actually reads it?

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Senator Herron. Does the minister agree that the explosion at Maralinga on 21 March this year, which has led to the suspension of the clean-up operation at the site of the British nuclear tests, throws serious doubt on the entire clean-up operation at Maralinga? Will the minister make the results of the investigations under way at Maralinga available to the parliament as soon as they are finalised, rather than wait for the quarterly report of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency? Can the minister also advise if the British government has been informed about the explosion? Finally, what assurance can the minister give that there will not be a repeat of this serious incident, either on resumption of in situ vitrification or under the proposed hybrid plan, which would still include vitrification?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Margetts for the question and acknowledge her concern about radiation problems, as we all share those concerns. I also know that Senator Margetts received a briefing on the Maralinga incident from the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency. The agency is monitoring the radiation safety aspects of the Maralinga clean-up, both for workers involved and for the environmental and public health outcomes of the operation. The Department of Industry, Science and Resources have ordered a thorough investigation of the incident by the project managers, which will then be independently audited. I suggest to Senator Margetts that this is the proper process that should occur and that she should wait until that process concludes. While the investigation is still under way, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency has ascertained that no staff were present within the exclusion zone at the time of the incident and there were no off site consequences nor any long-term implications for the radiological status of the site.

answer.para: At present, the reason for the explosion, as it were, or the gas leak, is not understood. It was apparently due to a mix of debris. On the basis of previous melts, the percentage of plutonium was estimated to be less than 100 grams in 400 tonnes, or less than 0.000025 per cent. Quantities of other radioactive materials are unknown but extremely unlikely to be of any significance compared to the plutonium, which is the reason for the process being used. The plutonium present in the pits as oxide is not combustible. I will check further with the minister to see if there is anything that can be added to that answer, and I will relay it back to Senator Margetts.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, by way of supplementary: can the minister advise how long the audit process is expected to take? I certainly would not agree that 100 grams of plutonium is something we should not consider very serious. What confidence can the community have that disposal of radioactive and toxic substances such as those at Maralinga can be carried out safely when incidents such as the explosion at Maralinga happened during the carrying out of what effectively is still an experimental process?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI understand that there are other processes that are being investigated in relation to this. I think we can accept with confidence that the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency is taking a keen interest in what is occurring in everybody's interests. I have not got a date for the conclusion of that investigation but, as I said in my previous answer, I think it should be allowed to follow due process so that a correct investigation can occur. Recommendations will then be put to the minister.

âMy question is to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask whether the minister can confirm the statement made by the Prime Minister yesterday on the Sunday program that:

question.para: By the year 2010 the states will be somewhere in the order of $15 billion to $20 billion a year better off than they would have been if the present system were to continue.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI do not have the transcript of that program. If Senator Sherry has got it, then presumably the answer is self-evident.

âObviously the minister does not know, and it is a very important issue. It is a fairly remarkable admission, frankly. So will the minister take the question on notice and return to the Senate with a detailed answer as soon as possible? It is a very important issue.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âAs I understood the question, it was: `Did Mr Howard say something on the Sunday program yesterday?' That is a matter of record, so presumably that will speak for itself. I will have a look at the transcript and send you a copy.

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Ellison. The Howard government has had a strong and ongoing commitment to young Australians, which has been clearly demonstrated by the number of youth and training initiatives introduced by this government. Could the minister please inform the Senate of some of these initiatives, particularly the one that has had the most outstanding successâthat is, the New Apprenticeship Scheme?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: âAt the outset, I thank Senator Knowles for that important question and acknowledge her commitment in relation to matters which affect the youth of this country. The Howard government is totally committed to seeing that the young people of Australia are well trained and properly skilled for the work force which they are about to enter.

answer.para: It is no surprise that, since 1996 when the Howard government came to power, there has been an increase of some 60,000 new apprenticeships, an increase of 60,000 people in training, which is a credit to the Howard government's reinvigoration of the training and apprenticeship system. That initiative was launched on 1 January last year, and it signified the introduction of flexibility for both the employer and the new apprentices. It allowed choice in training providers, and it also streamlined regulation which governed that training system. It expanded training opportunities in areas of rapid job growth, including new areas such as agriculture, sport, tourism and multimediaâall areas where we know there are great opportunities opening up for young people.

talk.start.para: âWhy has the failure rate gone up by 40 per cent?

âThe government has also provided 200 new apprenticeship centres which, as Senator Carr might be interested to know, are not only simplifying access to apprenticeships for young people but also providing support for employers. That is something which is of great assistance to employers in opening up opportunities for young people. But, in addition to that, we have provided some $43 million for the new Apprenticeship Access Program.
âWhat are you doing about the rorts?
âSenator Carr, you are persistently interjecting.

âThat is pretraining, if you like, which is allowed to be accessed by those people who need that preliminary training before being able to successfully participate in new apprenticeships. It is noteworthy that, for the first time, the number of people in apprenticeships and traineeships has now cracked the 200,000 mark. For the first time ever we have a record number of people in training: some 206,000 people in training. That is a significant achievement and one which points to the success of this government's initiatives in training and apprenticeships. I might add that the figures released last week by the National Centre for Vocational Education Research show increasingly strong growth in apprenticeship and traineeship numbers since that new apprenticeship initiative I have mentioned which occurred on 1 January last year.

answer.para: The figure of 206,000 is an increase of some 57 per cent on the figure of 131,000 which occurred in 1994 when Labor was last in power. That figure of 206,000 is an outstanding increase on what the Labor government could do. It is an indication that this government is committed to ensuring that the young people of Australia are job ready, that they do have the training necessary to meet their obligations in the work force. The success, of course, is in the numbers that I have mentioned.

But we have to look to the future. The federal government has announced that it will provide $485 million in financial incentives to employers and new apprentices for 200,000 commencements over the period May 1998 to November 1999. We will not just rest on that record figure, but we will do more because we realise that more has to be done. We are committed to providing 200,000 new places between May this year and November next year. This is an outstanding result; it is just one of the success stories of the Howard government in providing young Australians with further opportunities in training and securing a future for themselves. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former distinguished South Australian senator Mr Tony Messner. I welcome you to Canberra and trust that you will have a pleasant visit.

âMy question is directed to Senator Alston, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware of a statement by Minister Newman in the Senate on 16 February that `this government's GST package will help the poor and the needy'? Minister, how can this be so when, according to the government's own cameos, a single income couple with two dependent children, one aged under five years, earning $25,000 a year would only receive $21 per week to offset the new 10 per cent tax while the same type of family earning $75,000 a year would gain $121 per week?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âUnfortunately this is the union mind-set; in other words, `We're not so concerned about whether you're better off; we're concerned about how you stand relative to someone else.' So, if we are interested in a compensation package that is better than the existing arrangements and you improve someone's lot, what you say is, `Ah, well, if it doesn't improve it by exactly the same amount'âas some other group you can point toâ`then it's not worth doing.' That is the old command economy. That is classic relativities nonsense that I thought, when you were in government, you threw out the window. You believed in enterprise bargaining. You did not want equal outcomes. But here we go again, trying to pretend that somehow people lose as a result of our compensation package. Senator Evans did not get up and say that in as many words because he knows that the opposite is the case. What you do is point to the fact that you do not have precisely equal outcomes for all groups. But that is a very, very different proposition to saying that someone is worse off as a result of the changesâthey are not.
âWe didn't ask that.

âI know he didn't ask it. That is my point. That is where they do not want to know. You are into the politics of envy. What you do is go along to the commission and say, `I don't care whether Fred Smith gets another hundred bucks a week as a result of productivity changes in the workplace; that's not good enough because someone else at the same workplace is getting a hundred and fifty.' So it is a very bad outcome for Fred, is it? Of course it is not. Fred is $100 a week better off. That is what you are doing here. You are trying to pretend that, because you do not have a sameness of outcomes, people will lose. They do not. Let me say it time and again; as Mr Costello said:

answer.para: Professor Warren found that on average there appeared to be no groups who were losers. The fact is no group is worse off. The position of low income earners and pensioners has been safeguarded and it is therefore a fair package.

If Senator Evans wants to pretend that somehow this debate is about whether everyone gets the exact amount, then he is on another planet. He is not arguing the case; he is simply demonstrating why it is that Labor so comprehensively lost the last election.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, but I would point out to him that there are two issues at stake: one is the adequacy of compensation, and the other goes to the question of fairness. My question goes to that issue of fairness. Is the minister aware that the wealthier family's benefit is larger not only as a dollar amount but also as a proportion of income? The $25,000 family gains by 3.9 per cent of their income, while the $75,000 household gains by 12.5 per cent, well in excess of any possible inflationary effects of the new tax. Minister, is $21 for a family on $25,000 per annum and $121 for a family earning $75,000 per annum this government's idea of family values?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âMore than 20 years ago I went to Cuba. What I discovered was that, at the height of the system that you blokes were in love with, they had differentials of four to one between professional groups and unskilled workers. In other words, even Fidel Castro understood the need to have people on different levels. It might be an unfortunate fact of life that some people are born with more opportunities than others, and some people acquire more skills than others, but even Fidel Castro did not argue for an equality of outcomes. That is what you want. That is really what you are saying. It does not matter that some people earn more. Otherwise you would not have a progressive income tax scheme, would you? Do you resent the fact that high income people pay more taxes in order to subsidise those who are on low income earnings? This is a very fair package, and no-one has been able to demonstrate that anyone is worse off. (Time expired)
âMy question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services. I refer the minister to her statement of 9 April where she said:

question.para: . . . significant progress had been made towards providing unmet needs in disability service provision.

How is it that the minister can make such a statement when the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare estimates the cost of unmet need to be $293 million, of which $37.5 million is needed for accommodation alone? Why has this government put no additional funding on the table at the meeting of ministers responsible for disability services on 9 April?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI am glad to have the opportunity to answer that question because there is an agreement and a recognition across all governments in Australiaâstate, territory and federalâthat there is unmet need in disability services. The quantum of that unmet need was demonstrated by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare to be in the area of about $300 million. That was in a report which was provided to all governments at the disability ministers conference recently. I am very concerned that a decadeâtwo decades perhaps; I cannot quantify thatâof inattention to the needs of people with disabilities has now left our country, not any particular government, with this level of need for people who are some of the most vulnerable in our country. At the signing of the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement last year, it was agreed between the governments that the Commonwealth would convene a meeting of the governments within 12 months. The last signatory to that agreement was in June last year, and I convened this meeting in April, which I think is the quote you were referring to.

answer.para: As part of the disability agreement, a clause recognised that this meeting would be convened by the minister. It went on to sayâand I forget the exact wordsâ`Subsequently the ministers or the governments will determine how that will be met.' That is exactly what happened. I convened the meeting. The ministers endorsed the receipt of that important report from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. I indicated at that meeting that the Commonwealth was prepared to make a contribution to the unmet needs of people with disabilities.

I then asked the state representatives whether they were prepared to make that commitment, and they were not prepared to make that commitment at that time. While the media coverage subsequent to the meeting has been that the Commonwealth refused to make a commitment, it was not expected in the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement that the money was going to be discussed at that meeting. It was to be an assessment of the need and an acceptance of what the scale of the need was. That was done. If you look at the communique, all levels of governmentâCommonwealth, state and territoryâagreed that there was a shared role for meeting that need. It is now up to negotiations between the states, the territories and the Commonwealth to work out the degree of that sharing. We have made it quite clear to the states that we are prepared to make our contribution to that need.

Since the signing of that agreement in June last year, the Commonwealth has made two further commitments to the disabled in areas which are traditionally the responsibility of the statesânamely, respite for older carers of older people with disabilities and carers of profoundly disabled young people. All those millions of dollars in those commitments go to helping to meet the unmet need because they are respite areas, which is one of the three areas which the governments have all recognised. Accommodation, respite and day services are the high priority areas. So, while the outcomes might have been less than those with disabilities might have hoped, I believe progress has been made. Most of the disability organisations that I spoke to have expected it to take quite a while for that to be determined. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am pleased to hear that the government is very concerned over its apparent inability to meet these unmet needs, but people with disabilities are getting impatient. I ask the minister: exactly how much was the offer made to the states by the federal government and by the minister? What does the minister say to the 5,000 parents of children with severe and profound disabilities who cannot get proper supported accommodation? What does the minister say to the many elderly parents of disabled people and middle aged children who save the government millions of dollars by their personal sacrifices and who continue to be neglected and offended by the government's inaction?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI consulted pretty widely after I got this portfolio and before I met with the state and territory ministers about this. Consistently wherever I spoke to people they acknowledged that it had taken many years for this unmet need to reach this level and that it would not be achieved quickly in terms of dealing with it but that people with goodwill should be able to make a start. I believe we have made a start.
âHow much was it?

âI did not quantify the amount because I said to you at the beginning that nobody quantified their offer. We agreed, however, that we do have a shared role. You would be interested no doubt that some state representatives were suggesting that the role was to be met entirelyâ100 per centâby the Commonwealth. By the end of the meeting it was being acknowledged that it was a shared role, which is more realistic. The accommodation provision has been largely and historically a state role over many years. We are trying to help. (Time expired)
âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
