âI will take that interjection because all it says is that I was late in doing what I did. If I was late in doing it, it was because I was late in discovering the error. And what do I do in those circumstances: allow a flawed document to proceed, or exercise right and proper judgment to correct the balance and allow a properly balanced document to proceed? That issue is important here.

speech.para: In the last few minutes of this four-month hearing, and in the last few minutes of the testimony of Professor Harding and Professor Warren, it became clearâand it was corroborated by economic authorityâthat the so-called compensation awarded by the govern ment to pensioners in Australia would erode rapidly over time to zero; that these pensioners would have to pay a 10 per cent GST on costs, but what was awarded to them to compensate for doing so would vanish. This is a class of Australians who are the most unprotected Australians of all. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak about recycling and local government. It is some time since I last addressed the chamber on the dire predicament of kerbside recycling. But it is turning into a perennial bad news story, and little has changed in the last 12 months or so. Earlier this year 12 councils across Queensland were forced to shut down their recycling schemes because of expense, and other councils are currently reviewing their schemes. The Queensland Local Government Association attributes the failure to high costs and the refusal of the packaging industry to share responsibility for some of that waste.

speech.para: At present, federal, state and local governments and industry are negotiating the national packaging covenant, and included in this is a $35 million rescue package. This sum, to be spent over three years, falls well short of the $25 million a year needed by local government. The Queensland Local Government Association says that upgrading landfills to comply with state legislation in Queensland alone will cost around $700 million. So where is this money to be found? The story of recycling in Australia unfortunately can be summarised in one wordâand that is `buck-passing'.

Local government is expected to perform magic disappearing acts on the waste that we generate. We are a country with one of the highest recycling participation rates in the world; Canberra, at 80 per cent of households, has the highest in the country. It would be a tragedy to now subvert this painstaking public education campaign by which we have achieved this level of awareness and participation so far. One of the consequences of councils being forced to cut recycling services is a loss of public faith in environmental action.

Australia is a larger generator of waste than Canada, Europe and Japan and is exceeded only by the United States of America. Australians need to do a much better job in cleaning up our backyard. This entails cooperation. The net cost to local government of kerbside recycling is $75 million to $100 million a year. That is the gap between the cost of collecting and cost recovery, even taking into account the cost of avoided landfill. Such a cost is unsustainable. To lighten the burden on local government, federal and state governments, and particularly the packaging industry, need with some urgency to assume far greater responsibility for this problem. Local government is very wary of signing off on the $35 million rescue package because it is simply not adequate to meet the task of a genuine rescue effort. The industry contribution is a mere $17.5 million over three years, or one-ninth of the annual cost.

Recently the CEO of the Packaging Council of Australia, Mr Gavin Williams, said it did local government no honour to be calling for a higher industry contribution. I would suggest that the industry has got off very lightly. The majority of the cost of recycling is borne by ratepayers rather than governments or even consumers. There is little incentive at the moment for industry or consumers to clean up their act. As noted by the industry, there has been no action to date on importers of packaged products. These importers are under no compulsion to contribute to recycling or reprocessing.

The industry has said that it will not sanction its contribution to the rescue package being used to `prop up' kerbside recycling. What an extraordinary statement that is! What is often not taken into account is the real but often hidden cost to the community of landfill. All that is being asked of industry is to take more responsibility for the waste it produces. The use of the phrase `prop up' is not an entirely innocent use of language. Any expenditure for public or private good can be seen as propping up, depending on one's perspective. The general public props up private enterprise by paying taxes which are then used to construct roads which benefit private enterprise, particularly freight oper ations. Industry assistance, R&D funds and bailouts are some of the many projects that benefit from the public good, as does private enterprise that is propped up, usually by taxpayers.

This is not to say that there have not been councils that have signed unsustainable recycling contracts. The ALGA has said that efficiencies of up to 15 per cent in kerbside recycling could be achieved. But that would result in even more material flooding onto what is already a depressed market for recycled materials. In general, the public, especially ratepayers, have had to prop up an unsustainable cost to the environment of waste from packaging practices. Let us not forget that the Australian Supermarket Institute, one of the signatories to the covenant, is resistant to supporting measures such as charging consumers for plastic bags. We need to ask why it is that supermarkets cannot do what a host of small businesses and cooperatives are doing. I applaud the efforts of outlets such as Friends of the Earth grocery shops in capital cities, food cooperatives and the likeâoriginally the domain of universities but now spreading into inner suburbs.

According to the Australian Local Government Association, the cost of kerbside recycling has more than trebled in three years, thanks to burgeoning supply and the closure of overseas markets as a result of Asia's currency crisis. The ALGA has said:
Were it not for the fixed price of contracts for paper and cardboard, local government would be in a far worse position.

The net cost of kerbside recycling to local government in Sydney and Melbourne combined is $44 million per annum, and that is $9 million more than the poultry rescue package. One proposed solution is to allow councils to raise revenues through an identifiable surcharge, and this would entrench the status quo. It would not encourage industry to devise better packaging practices. The ALGA resolved in March last year to promote national container deposit legislation along the lines of the South Australian model. This may be the only alternative if industry and state and Commonwealth governments fail to provide adequate support for comprehensive recycling programs.

Back in 1984 a Victorian state government committee recommended the indefinite postponement of container deposit legislation. The industry then said it needed time to show that a voluntary effort would be preferable to a regulated outcome. As a result, the glass, aluminium and PET industries were instrumental in promoting kerbside recycling as an alternative to container deposit legislation, but it appears that the time for such industry optimism has now passed.

The New South Wales Local Government Association has called for a national week of action on container deposit legislation from 30 November to 6 December. A kit has been prepared in anticipation of this and the Democrats wholeheartedly support this initiative. It is my hope, however, that the campaign will be enthusiastically adopted by other states. It is one thing to consider ourselves tardy in adopting trends overseas, but it is quite another to ignore the success of the container deposit legislation on our own doorstep in South Australia. This is an idea that definitely needs recycling. It is one that I commend to the Senate. I hope the minister for the environment will at last take up this now urgent issue.

subdebateinfo.title: A New Tax System: Report of Senate Select Committee

talk.start.para: âI rise to add my thanks, as did Senator Cook, to a number of people who worked on the GST inquiry. In particular, I would like to thank Jody, Chris and Jan, who did an enormous amount of work on the committee in supporting Peter, Nick and me. I would also like to thank my staff, who had to put up with me right throughout the committee's inquiry.

speech.para: I rise on a matter of some importance. It is a matter I have raised in the committee and it is a matter that I have raised with the Clerk. It concerns the conduct of the Secretary of the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System, Mr Diamond.

A number of issues arose during the inquiry around the contract that Mr Murphy had with the committee. The committee had a number of heated debates about this matter. Mr Murphy did not complete his required work under the terms of the agreement that he signed. There were extensive discussions about why Mr Murphy did not. Mr Murphy claimed that he complied with the agreement and should be paid in full. I understand that the Clerk of the Senate and the President have now paid him in full. I believe that this payment is improper and that the conduct of the Senate has been reflected upon by the decision of the Clerk and the President, in particular, to pay this money.

Mr Murphy has not completed his written contract to this day and has, in fact, requested more money to complete his contract. When Mr Murphy was asked why he had not completed the work, he informed the committee that he had been told by a member of the committee secretariat that one of the quotes that he supplied was the one that was approved. Unfortunately, the deliberations of the committee did not reflect that point, because the committee did not agree to hire Mr Murphy for the quote that he gave.

The committee had an extensive discussion about it. What happened was that Senator Ferguson on behalf of the Liberal Party supported the existing quoteâknown as option 2âby Mr Murphy. I have no criticism of Senator Ferguson for that whatsoever. He supported that position, but the majority of the committee did not support that position. It is unfortunate that the secretary of the committee chose to reflect to the committee's staff that the position advocated by Senator Ferguson was in actual fact the majority position on the committee. It was not.

talk.start.para: âHave you checked with Senator Murray?
âIt was not, Senator Ferguson. Senator Murray has made the point in the committee processes which you have been engaged in with me.
âAddress the chair, please, Senator Conroy. Senator Ferguson, you will get your chance later.
âWhat has happened is that the Liberal Party's position was reflected by the secretary of the committee and, further, it was reflected in the verbal advice to the Clerk. This was not the case.

speech.para: We then had a second example where Professor Warren, in his presentation to the Senate committee just a week or so ago, stated clearly for the public record that, after he had been hired by the committee on a written contract to prepare certain work, he contacted the committee secretariat to advise them that he was not going to complete the work he had been contracted to do because, in his view, it was not able to be done. At no stage did the members of the committee consult with the chair of the committee about this matter; that is, about the fact that Professors Warren and Harding were not going to complete the work that they had been contracted to do.

Professors Warren and Harding made it quite clear that, as far as they were concerned, they had completed their contract. On the points that, in their view, they were not able to complete, they had contacted the secretariat of the committee and they considered that they had been discharged. They said that they believed that they were discharged from the responsibility of meeting the parts of the contract they either did not like, did not agree with or believed were too technically difficult to do. I have not been able to get a satisfactory answer as to why the committee secretariat took it upon itself to vary the terms of the contract that the committee itself had agreed to. So far no-one has even attempted to offer a suggestion after nearly two weeks. I ask: why was the chairman of the committee, Senator Cook, not approached and informed of this change by the committee secretariat? These are important matters.

The material that was contracted to be produced by this committee goes to the heart of the government's credibility. It goes to the heart of why Chris Murphy would not produce macro short-term effects as he was contracted to doâbecause they would have been critical of the government. It goes to the heart of why Professors Warren and Harding were able to phone the committee secretariat and say, `We don't want to produce first-year effects. It is too technically difficult.' This is not the case.
Senator Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat is what they said. Go and read the Hansard , Senator Ferguson.
âAddress the chair please, Senator Conroy.

âSo why did the secretariat, throughout the process of preparing the reports, continually not comply with the requests of the chair and the chair's representatives, the staff of the chair who were acting on his behalf and at his instruction? Given that the majority of the committee were requesting various changes at various points, why was Senator Ferguson continually able to thwart the production of the reportâas he did?

speech.para: Why were sections inserted, deleted and inserted? That is what has gone on with this particular committee report. Sections that were put in were taken out and then put back in. On whose instructions were sections taken out? Why was typing required to be done twice to put back in sections that had been deleted? This is a gross abuse of the Senate committee process. The committee secretary has no right whatsoever, if a majority of the committee want something in the report, to defy the chair.

It doesn't matter if Senator Ferguson phones you up and says, `I have discussed it with the Democrats; take this out, put that in.' With no reference to the chair whatsoeverâno checking with the chair as to whether this was an accurate statementâchanges were made to the report. This is an outrageous abuse by the Senate staff. It is unacceptable that the majority wishes of a committee can be thwarted by a minority position and a staff who do not want to comply. This is a very grave matter.

I come back to this: what was going on? There have been no answers yet from the committee secretariat as to why some material was agreed to, without the wish of the committee, by Professor Warren. He has said on the public record that he advised the committee and they said it was okay not to do the work. We are still waiting, two weeks later, to hear from anybody what transpired between Professor Warren and the committee secretariat.

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to speak on the matter of East Timor. As the Senate would be well aware, the situation in East Timor has deteriorated to a point where the so-called pro-Indonesian militia is undertaking a terror campaign towards the mass population of East Timorese. It is reported that at the very least 25 unarmed citizens were butchered last week in Liquica, a township just outside the main capital, Dili. The attack was on defenceless men and women inside a Catholic churchâa horrific scene. Within days the mob had moved their terror on to the capital of Dili. Armed to the hilt, the militia crisscrossed the city in convoys of trucks, firing at and attacking the houses of known pro-independence activists and of those who did not fly the Indonesian flag. The death toll in Dili at the very least was 12. Sadly, it is unlikely to stop there, given the Indonesian military's support of the militia. No-one should doubt that the militia have been armed and waved on by the Indonesian military. That chain of command goes all the way to Jakarta. Given that the military is still entwined with the government, at the very least the government must be held responsible and accountable.

speech.para: The history of East Timor under Indonesian rule shows that such bloodbaths are never the product of rogue elements. If Jakarta does not orchestrate it, then it is unhindered by Jakarta. The turn of events in East Timor places the country in grave danger of sliding into civil war with, consequently, the abandonment of the independence processâwhich of course is the prime aim of the militia. There is no doubt that following the abandonment of the independence process there would be an even greater suppression and slaughter of the population.

Therefore, there can now be no turning back from an East Timor policy. We need to make certain changes to and shifts in our policy and to change some of our current rhetoric. I believe that Australia should lock in behind this. Firstly, a new policy of frank engagement with Indonesia should replace the old policy of constructive engagement. Australia's policy of constructive engagement, first hatched after the East Timor invasion in 1975, has been a failure. It was a policy designed to get close to the Suharto regime, to win their confidence. We would therefore be in a position to influence the regime in areas of political, social and economic reform, to the advantage of the interests of Australia. Yet, for all this neighbourly bonding, we seem to have gained very little. The Suharto regime just ploughed on with its abuses, never making any meaningful reform. Today's announcement by the Prime Minister that he will meet with the Indonesian President, B.J. Habibie, next week for very urgent talks over the death toll in East Timor is such a shift in the policy. It introduces a direct engagement at the highest level. It is the needed shift in policy, and itâand far moreâis wholly supported.

Secondly, our stated preference for an autonomous East Timor in an Indonesian federation should be changed. How could we deny the East Timorese preference for total independence in the light of recent events? Thirdly, we should send the message to Jakarta that, no matter what it takes and regardless of the impact on our relationship, there will be a free vote regarding East Timor's futureâfree from intimidation and free from interference. This will send a clear message that there can be no backsliding on this matter. Fourthly, a frank engagement will require a whole new language to come out of Foreign Affairs. For example, the very soft language being used regarding the possible military backing of the militia or the suggestion that there is an inevitability in the path to freedom will bring about such atrocities as we saw in Liquica. Again today the Prime Minister has led the way and toughened up the language coming out of Foreign Affairs. He certainly conveyed a frank exchange between himself and the President of Indonesia when he said that there was `a strong and inescapable impression in Australia that the Indonesian military had not done enough to discourage the violence and discourage the killings'. Further, he said that ABRI had primary responsibility for maintaining security in Indonesia and that quite plainly that responsibility in East Timor had not been properly discharged.

Fifthly, we should no longer cover up what is coming through from our intelligence services. By putting it out there on the international stage, by being frank, we are going to have a more penetrative effect than the old way of diplomacy behind closed doors. Sixthly, Australia must gain an absolute commitment from Jakarta that they will immediately restore order by disarming the militia. If not, we must switch to supporting the call for a UN force to do the job instead and we must suspend all levels of military cooperation between Australia and the Indonesian armed forces.

Australia has a major role to play, indeed a proud role, in bringing a democratic vote to East Timor. But given the dark clouds now gathering over East Timor, a frank engagement is all we have time for before further atrocities occur. A new stance towards Jakarta will not be easy to enforce, with all its traps, but the alternative is worse; that is, a dishonest regime which is allowing East Timor to erupt into violence with all its terrible consequences, not just for East Timor but for the obvious flow-on effects for Australia.

subdebateinfo.title: A New Tax System: Report of Senate Select Committee

talk.start.para: âI want to make some comments about some remarks in the government senators' report that was tabled earlier today of the inquiry by the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System and also make a few comments about some of the remarks that Senator Ferguson made. Before I go to those, I would like to point out to the Senate that we are having a lengthy second reading debate on this issue. I do not want to cloud the issue relating to a goods and services tax with the comments I am going to make about the operation of the committee. It is important to note that the structure of the committees that were established to examine the tax package and the goods and services tax resulted from the deal between the government and Senator Harradine. It was a deal that led to the creation of, effectively, four Senate committees examining this package and it was the government's deal that set a very strict time line to report on what is the most significant tax package that has been put before the Australian community since Federation.

speech.para: In those circumstances, it is grossly hypocritical of the Treasurer and members of the government to criticise the moneys expended on the process. They were the ones who set up the structure. They were the ones who did the deal. In light of the $20 million of public moneys spent in the lead-up to the calling of the election, it was monumentally hypocritical. The deadlines that the committee was faced with in the preparation of reports and the hearings, et cetera, put us under enormous pressure, a greater level of pressure than I have ever encountered on any committee in my 9Â½ years here. That also put significant pressure on the committee staff and on the support staff, not just Labor opposition staff but also, I am sure, on the government staff and other parties who attended the hearings. In regard to that, I want to thank the three staff who were involved on the Labor side: Mr Chris Fry, Mr Jody Fassina and Ms Jan Southgate. In the circumstances, I think they did an excellent job, an outstanding job.

It is not unusual to have support staff carrying out the functions of examining documents for us, in some cases preparing questions and making suggestions about particular angles and issues that should be pursued and presented in the report. There is nothing unusual in that. It is common practice in most Senate committee hearings when reports are being conducted. It is particularly difficult for opposition parties. The government have vastly greater resources that they have used ruthlessly in pursuing their tax reform packageâtheir public expenditures of money on their advertising campaign. They have the backing and support of Treasury and the Department of Finance and Administration, as well as the personal staff in the various government members of the committee and also ministers' staffs. And that was apparent.

There were at least two staffers there to support the government. I do not complain about that. I just draw it to the attention of the Senate in terms of the imbalance of the allocation of resources. I think it was unfair. I do not get particularly upset or uptight about criticism of me or my colleagues on the Senate committee. I do get concerned though when I see unjustified criticism of staff who cannot defend themselves in this forum, particularly when they have been very dedicated in their pursuit of the issues that we had before us on the committee and provided us with invaluable assistance.

There were times when I got a little concerned with the behaviour of some of the support staff of the government, but I did not believe it appropriate to whinge or whine or carp about some of their activities. They did their job just as our Labor support staff did their job. It is very unfortunate that Senator Ferguson and the government senators chose to comment in the way they have in the report. It is often the fact that staff are critical in helping prepare the final reports. They have a very significant input. That is certainly not unusual.

There is also a reference here to Senator Conroy and me not attending a meeting to deliberate on the content of the report. That is not unusual in the Senate in committee reports. We often find ourselves in a position where we have other commitments. I note that of the 23 days of the sitting of the committee I attended all but two: for one, I had a pressing domestic matter in relation to the death of a relative and for the other, I had a longstanding commitment which I just could not break. We have other senators, very competent senators such as Senator Campbell who was, on this occasion, able to replace me. There was the same arrangement on the government side.

I commend Senator Cook, the chair of the committee. He sat through every hearing. I do not just commend him for that; I also commend him for the way in which he chaired the committee. So there was nothing unusual in my not being at a meeting to direct the final writing of the report. There have been occasions when I have not been involved in the process on other committees. It is no particular dereliction of duty and it is not an unusual circumstance. I daresay most senators in this place would, on one occasion or another, not get to the final meeting of the committee. We have an input; we had an input in this case. I discussed, I think probably on many occasions, on a daily basis with Senator Cook, the chairâthe very competent chair of the committeeâmy particular views, the particular issues, the angles that I wanted included in the final report. I had every confidence in Senator Cook to represent the concerns and the issues that I wanted included in the final report.

There is a reference in the report to government senators also wishing to note the `unacceptable behaviour of some Labor senators who at various times harassed and sledged some witnesses'. Certainly on this committee there were occasions when it got a little heated; occasionally it got terse. I have to say that, when some of the witnesses appearing before the committee gave evidence, particularly when they gave us some gross generalisationsâand I think the business community was outstanding for thisâabout the alleged benefits of the GST with no hard evidence, it got a bit trying at times. It got a bit trying for all of us. I do not think, on reflection, that on those 21 days I attended committee hearingsâ
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI am not going to mention the government senators. I do not want to pick on them.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou say, `Why not?' but we take it on the chin. There were occasions when government senators were getting stuck into witnesses, getting angry, getting uptight. It happens. But Labor senators, as I said, take it on the chin. It was a hard, grinding job. I actually enjoyed it. You get a bit tired at times and you get the occasional repetitive arguments, but we took it on the chin. We do not make any complaints about the behaviour of government senators. Their behaviour was, I think, identical to ours in terms of their approach.

speech.para: It certainly was not the worst committee I have ever served on. I recall the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operations of the Australian Loans Council. It would take a lot to top that committee, I have got to say, and time does not allow. The committee was led by the former Leader of the Democrats, Senator Coulter. It would take a lot to top some of the shenanigans that occurred on that committee. So I reject the government's criticism. I think it is unnecessary and, I think, particularly regrettable. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Night Freight Operations

talk.start.para: âI want to talk about an entirely different matter this evening because, in July last year, Sydney airport was forced to close its overnight freight operations from 11 p.m. on 6 July to 5.15 the following morning.

speech.para: Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âAnd, no, Senator Conroy, it was not the TWU.
âAnd Senator Conroy should not be interjecting out of his seat. He has been doing it repeatedly for the last while.

âI was not going to say that, Madam Deputy President. The result was a delay in the distribution of tonnes of mail and express freight and some very angry freight forwarders. One company, Australian Air Express, was reportedly so incensed it considered taking legal action to seek compensation. The then Minister for Transport, Mr Vaile, reacted as one would expect him to reactâhe was very angry. After all, this was the first time Sydney airport had been closed since the pilots strike of 1989 and he was the minister responsible. The minister, Mr Vaile, demanded an urgent report which was duly delivered to him on 13 July. He also sought an assurance that such an event would not happen again.

speech.para: Airservices Australia was forced to apologise to Sydney airport's major customers and also launched a full investigation into the problems encountered in finding replacement staff and the other issues that led to the incident. A Mr Peter Beaver undertook that investigation on behalf of Airservices Australia. He is the Manager, Corporate Security, at Kingsford Smith Airport.

The current minister has advised me, in answer to a question on notice, that Mr Beaver's inquiry covered contingency planning staff arrangements for that particular night and `findings in relation to individual staff members'. In fact, it is now clear that Mr Beaver, I assume on the instructions of the general manager, air traffic control, applied considerable effort in pursuing those controllers who called in sick that night. Mr Beaver, as part of his inquiry, was given access to a tape recording of the call from one of the sick controllers. He was also given access to all electronic and paper records relating to the circumstances surrounding the absence of the two staff members. He even gained access to their email accounts.

In a question on notice, I asked the minister whether these actions, which were extreme by any measure, were in contravention of an Airservices Australia union agreement. Mr Anderson answered that, because the tapes are recorded for operational security reasons, they are not covered by any agreement with the union. While the tapes might have been recorded for security reasons, they were certainly not accessed by Mr Beaver for that purpose. I also asked the minister whether Mr Beaver's actions were in breach of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. He said that, in the view of Airservices, the action did not breach the provisions of the act.

I have sought advice on this question and it appears that Airservices Australia is correct. It appears that, when communication is converted from electromagnetic form to speech at a telephone receiver, that act ceases to apply. It is not technically an interception. However, the actions of Mr Beaver may well be caught by the New South Wales Listening Devices Act which makes the use of a listening device to record a private conversation to which a person is not a party illegal. It appears the only defence available to Airservices would be if the personâthe air traffic controllerâexpressly or impliedly consented to the use of the listening device.

The minister also told me that Mr Beaver was given the authority to act as he did by the General Manager, Air Traffic Services. The minister offered to allow me access to the report that followed Mr Beaver's inquiry, and I will take him up on that offer. It is clear that the minister, Mr Vaile, was highly embarrassed by this incident, and so he should have been. But the then minister who was responsible to the people of Australia for aviation attempted to transfer that embarrassment to Airservices. Airservices Australia, it appears, then attempted to transfer responsibility to the controllers, and in pursuit of its quarry ignored the legitimate rights of those staff members and, it appears, the provisions of the Listening Devices Act 1984.

Under the enterprise bargaining agreement between air traffic controllers and Airservices Australia, controllers can access sick leave as required, and the employee is responsible for assessing his or her own fitness to attend for duty. I am sure that all senators would agree that if an air traffic controller is suffering from even a minor ailment that might impair his or her performance they should not present for work.

It is the responsibility of the shift supervisor to decide whether a replacement is required and to make arrangements as appropriate. That can involve the extension of a shift or the calling out of off-duty staff. That same enterprise agreement, which came into effect on 29 June last year, contained provisions regarding rostering principles as well as sick leave. Those rostering principles allowed for up to 10 days straight to be worked, including emergency duty and overtime. These principles were also a feature of the previous agreement that came into force in September 1992.

The Manager of Sydney airport, Mr Jim Ludlow, varied that rostering arrangement on 23 June last year. The number of consecutive days to be worked was reduced from 10 days to eight days. The reason given was that it was to address workload and fatigue concerns. According to the minister in an answer to a question on notice, the change was made `particularly in consequence of two safety incidents in which fatigue was a possible factor'. The minister advised me:
It was considered that regularly working the maximum 10 consecutive shifts could have been detrimental to staff health and attendance.
I asked the minister:
Under the eight-day rule, on how many occasions were operations at Sydney airport suspended due to a shortage of air traffic controllers?

He answered that the closure in July of last year was in part the result of this rule. The rostering arrangements introduced by Mr Ludlow were withdrawn on 9 July, just two days after the airport was forced to close. It is also important to note that, prior to the forced closure of Kingsford-Smith Airport, Airservices Australia's senior management had been alerted, over a period of time, that the airport was vulnerable to closure on night shifts due to the staffing arrangements. Let me again quote the minister on this important point. He said:

Airservices Sydney management had been made aware of potential deficiencies in the contingency plans applying in the event that there were not sufficient rated air traffic controllers available to maintain normal operations.

The main factors directly contributing to the closure of the airport in July were high sick leave levels, the contingency arrangements that were in force at the time and the late notice given by a night shift controller. However, the key issue here was not two sick air traffic controllers, as the minister and Airservices Australia would have us all believe. The real problem was, and still is, the management of change in Australian aviation generally and the operation of Kingsford-Smith Airport in particular.

Like many other areas of public administration under the Howard government, the administration of aviation policy is, frankly, a shambles. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigations report B98/90, entitled Systemic investigation into factors underlying air safety occurrences in Sydney terminal airspace, released in August of last year stated:

Notwithstanding the likelihood that there has been resistance to some elements of change at Sydney TCU, the sheer volume and scope of the change process appears to have been overwhelming for most air traffic controllers.

There is a safety issue here, and there is also a human resources problem. There is also a minister trying to achieve certain objectives, and those objectives are: firstly, a political distribution of noise from the airport over Sydney, an objective which now appears to be satisfying no-one; secondly, a program of capacity enhancement at KSA, that program having become disjointed and problematic; and, thirdly, establishing an airport that can cope with the demands of the 2000 Olympics, and this now is becoming increasingly unlikely, especially if the weather is bad. And, of course, Mr Anderson now, like Mr Vaile before him, brings an obsession with both privatisation and cost reduction to the pursuit of these objectives. It should be becoming increasingly obvious that the manner in which Mr Anderson is administering his portfolio when it comes to aviation safety leaves a lot to be desired.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, it has been years since I spoke on an evening adjournment, but I feel it necessary to respond to some of the things that have been said on the adjournment by Senator Cook, Senator Conroy and Senator Sherry.

speech.para: Senator Bolkus interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI will start with some of the things that were said by Senator Cook. He commenced his contribution by saying that I was critical of his staff, or of the staff that worked for him. Senator Cookâthrough you, Madam Deputy Presidentâ
âYes, please address the chair and ignore the interjections.
âMy criticism is not directed at the staff; it is directed at you.
âAt the chair?
âBecause, as chairman of this committee you allowed the job of the chairmanâ
âSenator Ferguson, you might get yourself into less trouble if you actually speak to me and refer to Senator Cook in the third person.
âI did not notice you saying that to Senator Conroy, Madam Deputy President, but I will defer to your ruling.
âShe did, actually. Check the Hansard . She did twice.
âI did ask you to address the chair.

âCan I say, Madam Deputy President, that if the chairman had fulfilled his duty correctly and had come to the complete finalisation of this report, then perhaps his staff would not have been involved in things that are the work of senators and not of staff. At no stage during my contributions at the second reading stage on the ANTS bills did I do anything other than report accurately what happened during the process. It was the process that I was critical of, and not the individuals that were involved. It was just that they should not have been doing the things that they were doing in the role in which they were doing them after a deadline had been passed and after a committee had determined that deadline. As I said, I could have brought down the faxes, because I brought them to Canberra. I have 64 pages of faxes that I received after the deadline, which had changes in them to the committee report which we had been discussing during the week.

speech.para: I think it was Senator Conroy who said that I had suggested to the secretariat that certain things be deleted. Senator Conroy, there is only one sentence in the whole of the report that was put to me that I asked to be deleted. To his credit, Senator Cook, along with Senator Murray, agreed that that should go out. Otherwise, all we wanted to do was to add to the report to put what we thought was balance back into what had been a biased interpretation of the evidence we had received as a committeeâone that was heavily weighted in favour of the Labor Party's position and not a balanced report of the situation as it was presented to us.

Senator Cook, as chairman, should have fulfilled that role. If, as Deputy Leader of the Labor Party in the Senate, which is a very demanding role, he chooses to take on the job of chairman of a select committee as wellâanother shadow minister and a former parliamentary secretary were also on the committeeâthen one role has to come first. If he takes on the role of chairman of what he says is an important committee then, in fact, that job should come first.

I noticed that Senator Sherry praised Senator Cook because he attended all 23 hearings. Can I say that was because of the fact that, on the days that Senator Cook was not available, we did not sit. I think Senator Cook would concede that we changedâ

talk.start.para: âThat is outrageous.
âOrder on my left! Senator Conroy.

âYou would concede, Senator Cook, there were a couple of occasions when I agreed we should not sit that day because you had to receive medical treatment. It is a fact that we did not sit. Senator Conroy, Senator Cook and Senator Sherry all thanked their staffâJody, Chris and Jan. They have every right to thank them, because if it had not been for Jody, Chris and Jan, Senator Conroy would not have had a question to ask any witnesses. He would not have had any questions at all. He used to come along with a wad about so thick, which Mr Jody Fassina or Mr Chris Fry would supplement as they went through it. Senator Conroy just about wore out the carpet between his advisers and his seat on the inquiry because he could not think of any questions himself. The only questions he ever asked were questions that were supplied by staff. And he says it is an outrageous attack on the integrity of people who cannot defend themselves.
âI did not.
âYes, you did; you said the staff could not defend themselves and you saidâ
âSenator Cook said that, not me.

âI am sorry, I have got it under Conroy; it must have been you. Can I say that that is nothing like your outrageous attack on another staff member who cannot defend himself. You named the secretary of a committee; someone who has been in this place, I understand, for in excess of 20 years. I would suggest, Senator Conroy, that if you want to check whether or not this person has done a correct and proper job over the history of his service in the Senate, you should consult with all of your former Labor colleagues who have worked with Mr Diamond over that long period of time and see whether they agree with your statement.
âIt is what he did on this committee that matters.

âIf you can find one, you let me know. Unfortunately, Madam Deputy President, Senator Conroy has the view that if someone is not totally supportive of everything that he says or does then they must be against him. We all know in the Senate that there are a variety of views and there always will be a variety of views. Poor old Senator Conroy just cannot take it when there is somebody who does not accede in every way to every request that he makes.

speech.para: He then criticises the decision of the Clerk and the President. Now whether you were accusing the Clerk of bias as well, Senator Conroy, remains to be seen; but I will look very closely at the Hansard tomorrow, because when the Clerk gives advice to the President they make a decision with all of the evidence before them. In fact, Senator Cook, as chairman, and I both met with the President and the Clerk. You were not present at that meeting, Senator Conroy, so it would be very difficult for you to know what took place at that meeting. You talk about a Liberal Party submission to the Clerk. I have never made a submission to the Clerk. I spoke at that meeting with Senator Cook. He is aware of what was said and we both had what was an amicable meeting with the Clerk and the President. The decision was left to the Department of the Senate, who should determine that. If, after your accusations, the documentation of everything that went on at those meetings is possibly made public in the future then, in fact, others will be the judge of whether or not you have a very biased opinion of what is happening.

You then bring into question Professor Warren's and Professor Harding's contract. To the best of my knowledge, that has not been discussed by the committee. It was raised in evidence but has never been discussed by the committee. I can only assume by the remarks you made tonight that, in fact, you now do not want to pay Professor Harding, or Professor Warren either, for the work that they have done. It seems to be the case with Senator Conroy that if everything does not come out exactly the way he wants it, then he tries to discredit people.

Senator Conroy, I thought your contribution tonight was very poor. I think that if you read through the Hansard you might reflect on some of the things that you have said. I know that you tried to be very careful. I could see that you were really tryingâyou usually are very trying. I think you should read it carefully, because I imagine the Clerk and others in the Senate will want to read very carefully what you have said. But I hark back to what I said: if you want to be critical of someone who works in the Department of the Senate, who has a long history of respect and a long history of work in this place, I suggest you go to some of your existing colleagues and some of your former colleagues and see whether or not they would agree with your criticism.

I never suggested that anybody should not have support staff because, in the context of a complicated inquiry like this, it is absolutely essential that support staff are available. The Labor Party had their support staff and we had our support staff. Without them I am doubtful whether we could have dealt with all the matters that were canvassed.

Let me tell you this: when it comes to writing the report, that is the responsibility of the senators and the senators themselves. It is not the responsibility of staff to go directly to secretariats to initiate changes, which in fact the chairman himself would have been unaware of at the time because they were only faxed to him as well. Senator Sherry says that it is much more difficult for opposition parties. We did not find it that way, Senator Sherry. Senators themselves, particularly backbench senators, always made sure that they did their work, they did their homework. When we were in opposition we never had to get staff to write reports.

I know the other senators have had 40 minutes, double time, to get their point across tonight. I may have to have a bit more time tomorrow night. Senator Sherry also spoke about the structure of committees. He did not say that they were dominated by the Labor Party. Even in the select committee, when the Democrats senator chose not to vote on any issue it gave the Labor Party the majority because when the vote was three-all it meant that Senator Cook could put into the report exactly what he wanted. (Time expired)
